posts.text:
What is the value of a life? ü§î

An Economist‚Äôs POV:

The value of a life is an economic value used to quantify the benefit of avoiding a fatality. 

By placing a monetary value on life, it enables decision making regarding the allocation of scarce resources like infrastructure, labour, and tax revenue.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) is a US government body and it estimated the value of a statistical life at¬†US$7.5 million¬†in 2020.


My POV:

Life is either worth nothing,

or its worth everything,

and its not worth nothing.


Substack: https://lnkd.in/e-pPYZba

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
Is a bird without wings still a bird?

This question haunted me during Q3 2024 as I faced one of my toughest decisions yet.

Check out my previous posts for Q1 & Q2. Here's Q3:

üåü JULY: The leap of faith

‚ö´Ô∏è Dove into Harvard's CS50 - Looking behind the curtain of tech products was enlightening. After years of being just a tech user, I was shocked to realise these revolutionary products were just clever combinations of 0s and 1s. The first few weeks were tough, but learning felt great.
‚ö´Ô∏è Made the journey more fun - Working for myself meant true autonomy. With just a laptop and WiFi, I turned parks, art galleries, coffee shops, and libraries into my office. My imagination became my only limit.
‚ö´Ô∏è Runway Extension - Made the tough decision to move back home. As a young adult who'd spread their wings, returning to the nest felt like having them clipped. Is a bird without wings still a bird?
‚ö´Ô∏è Hit my second consecutive 100km running month (101.7 km in 10+ hours)

üöÄ AUGUST: No wings required

‚ö´Ô∏è Moving home transformed my life - Reconnecting with my parents awakened dormant parts of me. Without the weight of survival, I began to thrive. A full fridge and clear mind put me in a state of play.
‚ö´Ô∏è Found my North Star - Discovered Pieter Levels, whose lifestyle and approach to building became my blueprint for the future.
‚ö´Ô∏è Leveled Up - Completed Harvard's CS50, building Sands as my final project - an app helping people live more intentionally through visual time management.
‚ö´Ô∏è Reality Check - The course was just the beginning. Building production-ready applications would require much more than CS50 could offer. Time to dive deeper.
‚ö´Ô∏è Kept moving - Completed 20 runs, covering 107.6km in just under 10 hours.

‚ö° SEPTEMBER: You have a plan until you get punched in the face

‚ö´Ô∏è Ambitious Plans - I wanted to learn how to build production-ready applications, and I wanted to do it as fast as possible. I set a challenge for myself: clone and build 30 major tech company's product in 30 days. Looking back, my optimism was both admirable and hilariously wrong.
‚ö´Ô∏è First Real Build - My first production-ready app was Creatorr. It generated conversations, code, music, images, and videos using OpenAI and Replicate APIs. I started the app on 4th September, and it took me 15 days to complete. One app down, twenty-nine to go... or so I thought.
‚ö´Ô∏è Body's Reality Check - A football injury turned into a cascade of problems when I rushed back too soon. I ran 65km in a week and I destroyed my legs. By the end of the week, my left ankle, knee and shin felt like lead; it felt so brittle that any pressure would easily snap the bone. I struggled to walk and was homebound for four days.

---
üëãüèª I‚Äôm a Founder in London building my startups, and sharing my journey & learnings along the way so others can do the same.

Follow for startup secrets & resources!

Full post on my Substack (2024 wrapped - living on mercury)

#Entrepreneurship #startup

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
The quarter that shattered plans, perspectives, and limitations. Here's the Executive Summary of Q2 2024.

April: Customer Discovery üéØ

‚ö´Ô∏è After 40+ customer interviews, I developed a Proof-of-Concept of my app using no-code tools. I realised I needed serious technical muscle to take it further as I needed to process 1000s of datapoints.
‚ö´Ô∏è Met two founders working on a similar idea, and we decided to join forces.
‚ö´Ô∏è I went on 17 runs, accumulated 110.5 km and spent 11:29:00 hours running.

May: The Adjustment ‚ö°Ô∏è

‚ö´Ô∏è I hoped working with two additional individuals would triple the productivity. Instead, it divided it by three.
‚ö´Ô∏è On 10th May, in our morning meeting, I highlighted my concerns and decided to part ways. I couldn't wait for 'things to click'. I have been in many co-founding relationships, and when I observe red flags, I don't wait for things to go wrong.
‚ö´Ô∏è After the co-founder breakup, I was on my own again. There is no other way to say it ‚Äî I felt shit. 
‚ö´Ô∏è I switched gears. I set the goal of developing the Minimum Viable Product (MVP) myself.
‚ö´Ô∏è On 20th May at 8:20pm, I opened Visual Studio Code for the first time. By 4:07 am, I'd written my first bit of Python code. Watching my code process data changed me. I realised what I thought was my global maximum was just my local maximum.
‚ö´Ô∏è My running really took a hit from the co-founder breakup. By 14th May, I only ran 25.34 km. I returned on the 23rd and tried to recuperate as much as possible. I ran 40 km that week, bringing my total to 65.34 km.

June: My Love-Hate Affair with GPT üíªüíî

‚ö´Ô∏è Back on track: 16 runs, 100 km, 10:27:21 hours running.
‚ö´Ô∏è I spent the first half of June talking to OpenAI's GPT. I'd tell GPT what I wanted, get the code, put it into VS code, test it out, and then repeat‚Äîover and over and over and over again. I pulled a few all-nighters doing this. There was something so addicting about it.
‚ö´Ô∏è While I was making progress, this experience was extremely frustrating. GPT isn't perfect, and bits of code were deleted whenever I asked for revisions.
It got so frustrating that I started giving GPT prompts in caps locks. "FIX THIS PLS"; "WHAT ARE YOU DOING?"; "YOU'RE NOT LISTENING TO ME". I don't know what I hoped to achieve with this because I was talking to a robot, but I was running out of options.
‚ö´Ô∏è By the end of June, I snapped. I needed to readjust my approach because I didn't want to be #1 on GPT's kill list once AI took over and I'd probably lose my sanity before GPT got to that stage. I needed to stop being a mindless monkey and understand what the code was doing. 
‚ö´Ô∏è I started Harvard University's CS50‚ÄîIntroduction to Computer Science course to achieve this.

üî• Part 3 coming on Monday: Follow to stay updated!

Want the full story? Check out my deep dive on Substack: https://lnkd.in/eJMmfdm2

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
From rejection to winning my first AI hackathon: My Q1 2024 Entrepreneur's Journey üöÄ

Learning: Entrepreneurship is not a linear journey. Be prepared to start at the bottom of a non-linear curve.

I got many questions about my 2024 Wrapped Entrepreneur's Edition, so I decided to break it down. Here's my unfiltered ride through Q1 2024 - from an Antler rejection that shook my confidence to winning my first AI hackathon.
A thread on pivots, persistence, and finding your path: üßµ

January: The Reset üìä

‚ö™Ô∏è I was in a bit of a rut because I had not received an investment from Antler. Being so close to achieving my goals, yet so far, really messed with my head.
‚ö™Ô∏è I needed a source of income, so I started applying for jobs in sales, startups, venture building, venture capital, and investment banking.
‚ö™Ô∏è I applied for jobs, but I knew in my heart that I wanted to have my own business. I decided to use my previous sales and consulting experience. I had the idea of a Sales Automation Agency‚Äîa hybrid model‚Äîa mix of Consulting and SaaS. Many of the Founders in my network had no idea how to grow and scale their businesses, so I thought my services could bring them value.
‚ö™Ô∏è I went on 17 runs, covered 92.79 km and spent 9:26:30 hours running.

February: Planning & Building üõ†Ô∏è

‚ö´Ô∏è I built the Sales Automation Agency; I decided to call it Outbound Hero. I know LinkedIn like the back of my hand, and with this knowledge, I helped a few pre-seed and seed-stage companies develop their Sales and Go-to-Market strategies. I laid the foundations for market entry into their designated verticals.
‚ö´Ô∏è Continued applying for jobs. I started to get interviews, but the positions could have been more desirable. I did the interviews anyway.
‚ö´Ô∏è I went on 13 runs, covered 96.29 km and spent 9:10:48 hours running.

March: Plot Twist üîÑ

üü£ Continued applying for jobs. The count was up to 250+ applications at this point. I began to despise ATS systems and just the general hiring process. I got tired of constantly having to sell myself.
üü£ Sunset Outbound Hero. Learning: I enjoyed working with Founders, but the agency model was unscalable. It required more face time than I had anticipated. My clients (pre-seed/seed stage startups) wanted my help, but they couldn't afford my services.
üü£ I got hit by a car near Waterloo as I was cycling. I was fine. I had minor injuries, but my bike can't say the same. I want to say that my life flashed before my eyes, but it didn't. The only flash was that of a blue BMW. Learning: Life can end in an instant, be grateful for each moment.
üü£ I went on 15 runs, hit 100.6 km, and spent 8:42:18 hours running.
üü£ I went back to the drawing board to generate software ideas. After Outbound Hero, I wanted to build a pure SaaS business. I started to generate a few ideas.
üü£ I entered my first AI Hackathon (Hosted by Encode) and won.

üî• Part 2 coming on Thursday
ü™ê Detailed breakdown: https://lnkd.in/eJMmfdm2

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
What if entrepreneurs had their own Spotify Wrapped? Here's mine for 2024 üëá

Hey LinkedIn üëãüèª
It's been 7 months since my last post, and A LOT has happened since then.
I thought of the best way to catch you up on all the material updates, and then I thought of Spotify.

Every year, Spotify transforms our listening habits into beautifully digestible stories through its Wrapped campaign. I love how they turn raw data into meaningful narratives.

I decided to do the same for my year as an Entrepreneur.
üéÅ Introducing the world's first Wrapped - Entrepreneur's Edition üéÅ

What's inside:

Building üõ†Ô∏è
üßëüèª‚Äçüíª Apps developed
üíª Tech stack evolution
üß† Skills gained & outputs delivered

Growth üìà
ü§ù Relationships built
ü´Ä Health & fitness journey
üêâ Character development & challenges faced

Investment ‚è≥
Total time invested in the entrepreneurial journey

Swipe to see my 2024 wrapped in raw numbers - including the highs, lows, and everything in between! üìä

--

‚ÑπÔ∏è About Entrepreneur Wrapped ‚ÑπÔ∏è 

Why hasn't it been done before?

1. It's hard to track and analyse metrics across all the activities you do as an Entrepreneur
2. It's hard to be honest and authentic about the trials and tribulations you face along the way
3. It's hard to show the world who you are 

Why did I do 2024 Wrapped?

Personal reasons:
1. Management guru Peter Drucker says, "What gets measured gets managed". If you want to improve something, you need to measure it.¬†This year's data gives me a baseline. Next year, I work harder, and I work smarter.

2. Everything has a price. I consider this Wrapped as my receipt for this year as an Entrepreneur. The time I invested and what I went through is the price I'm paying to get what I want. By tracking this year-on-year (YoY), I can track the accurate price of Entrepreneurship.

Social reason:
To bridge the gap between expectations and reality by sharing authentic entrepreneurial experiences. NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang said the pain and suffering he experienced starting the chip giant would be enough to put him off ever doing it again. I understand his perspective because this year, I lived on Mercury. I didn't expect this, but the pain and suffering was real. I hope this Wrapped (and all future content):

1. Inspires entrepreneurs to share their journeys authentically; 
2. Educates and informs aspiring entrepreneurs about the journey they are about to embark on.

Want to dive deeper into what living on Mercury really means?
I wrote about my journey in 2024 on Substack: https://lnkd.in/d3rhJpUf

--
Have a Merry Christmas, and a Happy New Year! üéâ

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
What do you need to know to start a startup? ü§î

Starting a startup is no joke.

It‚Äôs a long, tough journey and most of the startup‚Äôs value will come after 10+ years. The graph below shows market capitalisation over time (Chart by James Currier at Nfx).

Therefore, if you‚Äôre in it for the long run, you should prepare adequately for the journey.

Imagine you are preparing to run a marathon - yes, you could show up on the day without any training or nutritional plan and grind through it, but you‚Äôll¬†probably have a terrible time doing it (and it won‚Äôt be fun).

Startups are the same.

Over the next few weeks, I‚Äôll share some of the ways I've prepared for this journey.

I appreciate we learn differently. Therefore, in the spirit of inclusivity, I'll share content that can be consumed via text, audio and video.

Today, it is about text. üìù

These are a few of the books I‚Äôd recommend reading and one key insight I learnt from them.

üìö Zero to One (Peter Theil) - Don‚Äôt compete, aim to be a monopoly. 

If you have an undifferentiated product, you will always be battling your competition, and war is bad for business. This market state is great for the consumer, but not so great for the producer (startup) as your profits will get competed away. No profits = no way to reinvest and improve your product.

üìö Start with why (Simon Sinek) - Start with why. 

People don‚Äôt buy what you do, people buy why you do it. History is littered with stories of people who have strived towards the same goal, but some succeed and others don‚Äôt. I love the example of the Wright brothers inventing the¬†airplane. There was competition from a better-funded team led by Samuel Pierpont Langley, but we all know who won that race.

üìöThe code of an extraordinary mind (Vishen Lakhiani) - You get to pick the rules. 

We¬†aren‚Äôt asked¬†to be born into this world, and when we are, we keep getting told things should be the way they are because of 'X' or 'Y' reasons. Vishen says these are ‚ÄòBrules‚Äô. You have the autonomy to choose, and you should pick the rules that work best with the type of life you want to live.

Let me know if this was helpful and drop some of your favourite books in the comments section below ‚¨áÔ∏è

P.S Bonus content: A summary PDF of The Code of an Extraordinary Mind here -https://lnkd.in/dbMmwZG4

#sharingiscaring #socialcapital

posts.text:
Executive summary:
- Three quarters through 2019, annual European M&A value and volume are apace to be the lowest readings since 2014 and 2010, respectively.
- Despite economic confidence languishing across the continent, German M&A in 2019 has been solid.
- With one quarter remaining in 2019, healthcare deal value has already topped 2018‚Äôs total and could potentially reach an all-time high. 

#mergersacquisitionsdivestitures

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
Some key takeaways from the report:

1. There are 187 active unicorns in the US with an aggregate value of just over $600bn. This marks a small decline from its peak of $603.3bn in 2018. 

2. Enterprise-dedicated platforms are in vogue as investors see a more clear path to profitability in this sector.

3. There has been growing participation of nontraditional VCs. These nontraditional and foreign players seek exposure to fast-growing tech-companies in order to diversify their own portfolios. 

4. 2019 so far has been the year of record exit values. 14 exits which include $15.3bn in acquisitions of unicorns and $142bn in IPO value. This could be the start of a trend where you see cash-rich tech giants acquire these unicorns more actively. 

#trend #vcs #unicorns

posts.text:
"But younger funds tend to report higher IRRs for a given TVPI level anyway; a shared TVPI of 1.5x between two funds will translate into different IRRs depending on the vintage‚Äîthe younger of the two will have distributed capital back to LPs quicker, justifying its higher IRR and muddying the water on the inflation question."

#pe #capital #inflation

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
Exits experienced an even greater downturn than deals. Public equity price decreases in 4Q 2018 likely led to GPs marking down portfolio companies, though to a lesser extent than seen in public indices. GPs instead held portfolio companies and awaited a friendlier selling environment. 1Q 2019 saw just one PE-backed IPO as GPs instead opted to sell portfolio companies to other financial sponsors or strategic acquirers, continuing recent trends. Market tranquillity was sustained throughout the end of the quarter, so we expect the 1Q lull in exit activity to be short-lived.

Fundraising‚Äîunlike deals and exits‚Äîis on pace to match 2018‚Äôs annual total with over $40 billion raised in the first quarter. Fewer but larger funds are closing, pushing median and average fund sizes even higher. Strategies beyond the vanilla buyout continue to proliferate, with technology focused and growth equity funds witnessing massive closes. The recent figures also speak to a longer-term change whereby GPs headquartered in the Bay Area and Chicago accounting for a swelling portion of capital raised.

Read more here...

#privateequity #exits #fundraising

posts.text:
Companies such as Uber and Lyft are somewhat insulated from bearish market sentiment having an impact on their IPOs due to their large scale and maturity‚Äîthe median valuation of a tech IPO in 2008 was just $106 million, while Uber and Lyft could have a combined valuation in excess of $100 billion.

Read more in our Primer:
https://lnkd.in/ebJzHxZ

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
A couple of noteworthy points: 

1. Greg Becker, CEO of Silicon Valley Bank: Compared with tech IPOs, there is a very different metric; most biotech companies at IPO have no revenues. Instead, they seek IPO proceeds to capitalize additional years of research and development, targeting a new
drug approval.

2. Series A is the new Series B: early-stage and angel & seed median deal sizes travelled higher in 2018, reinforcing the idea that the profile of companies at each venture investment stage has shifted across the entire venture funding cycle.

3. The exit market recorded robust activity throughout 2018, with total exit value eclipsing $120 billion for the first time since 2012

Read more:

author.name: Lobsang Lama
author.headline: Full Stack Founder | Building startups & helping others do the same

posts.text:
Florian Thaler, The CEO and Co-founder of OilX talked to PitchBook about the change that is coming:

"Commodity trading and oil trading as the largest commodity will be significantly shaped by two mega-trends, namely new data sets from remote sensing via satellites, as well as superior data science models that can process, curate and combine data in near real time on a massive scale."

posts.text:
This is my first Linkedin post and it's a rather important one!

I'm happy to confirm that I have now completed my business plan! I am now looking for a technical co-founder with web development/app development capabilities to collaborate with to create a minimum viable product (MVP). It's perfectly fine to not have relevant experience as I'm really just looking for someone who is passionate, motivated and most importantly, willing to learn and adapt.  

I believe my idea has great potential to disrupt the holiday industry so if you are interested in this opportunity (or know someone that is interested) please do not hesitate to message me or email me on lobsangnlama@hotmail.co.uk where we can discuss it further.

"Those who are crazy enough to think they can change the world usually do" -Steve Job

#startups #startupventures #businessplan #webdevelopment #teambuilding #venturecapital #cofounder
